I think that you mean "entropy". You must remember that entropy and the law of thermodynamics apply to a closed system. Also, in Empiricism or in Science there is no such thing as an "absolute truth" or an "irrefutable fact". Science is based on observation. 
 
 Although there is change, there is also a state of "steadiness" - of equilibrium. For an electron there is a positron, for matter there is anti-matter. The statement, "there are no absolutes" is self-contradictory since it proposes that it is itself an absolute. Since there cannot be absolutes by the statement, it makes it paradoxical. By Reductio Ad Absurdum we might prefer its contrapositive - that there are absolutes.
 
 Change alone is unchanging. 
 ~~Heraclitus (c. 535-c. 475 B.C.), Greek philosopher. Herakleitos and Diogenes, pt. 1, fragment 23, trans. by Guy Davenport (1976). 
 
 There's nothing constant in the world,
 All ebb and flow, and every shape that's born
 Bears in its womb the seeds of change. 
 ~~Ovid (Publius Ovidius Naso) (43 B.C.-A.D. 17/18), Roman poet. Metamorphoses, 15. 177-178.

 Nope, nope and nope. In symbolic logic, "-<" does not mean equals. "=" is equals. -< represents a conditional statement. If A -< A; A :: A -- by Modus Ponens. The statement is also, in fact, biconditional and we can express it as so, A <-< A. This statement, and the one I proposed is a clasically tautology. You have, unfortunately, confused a tautology with the other regular analytical truths. Tautologies are the only analytical statements that are always true. It might help if you look up one or two of the truth tables on the Internet. A statement like, "I am a boy", is analytically true because it follows from my age. However, tautological statements are more like, "I am who I am" (God in Exodus) or "All crows are black or they are not". 
 
 I do not understand what you mean by saying that it is "excluding from being wrong". I do not know what you mean by wrong, but it is certainly invalid. A paradox is, ipso facto, invalid and self-contradictory.

Okay, I'll explain it again now - so try to take this in.
 
 A tautology is an analytic truth that is always true. It is normally independant of definitions and not reliant on them. A statement such as "that bachelor is a man" is a clear cut analytic truth. Its truth value is determined by the definition of a bachelor. Since, for one to be a bachelor, he must (i) be male and (ii) be unmarried. What you really missed, is the vital nature of the tautology:
 
 A -< A
 
 This statement is the same as A <-< A. That is to say, it is tautological. For the moment, let's put aside the I Am, and let's take another one that might be easier to deal with. "-<" is a conditional statement and, for the moment, you'll do well to just read it as an "If... then". Therefore, what we are saying above is, "If A, then A".
 
 So now, let D = Dogs are fat. 
 
 D -< D
 
 What we're saying here is, "If dogs are fat, then dogs are fat". This is true by the rule in logic called Modus Ponens. Modus Ponens states:
 
 A -< B; A :: B
 
 We have reached the conclusion that all crows are not black by inductive methods - not deductive. If we define a crow as black, then all crows are black. That is a tautology. However, "All crows are black or they are not black" logically follows from the law of excluded middle. 
 
 A tautology has often been defined as "saying the same thing twice" - which can often fit very well. It often provokes circular reasoning. You might also do well to think of it as the opposite to a paradox. While a paradox is always false, a tautology is always true. If you are having further trouble understanding the nature of a tautology, search for some truth tables on the Internet - they might make things clearer.
